Through regeneration Christ came into our spirit ([link]2 Tim. 4:22[/link]). After this, we should allow Him to spread into every part of our heart. Since our heart is the totality of all our inward parts and the center of our inward being, when Christ makes His home in our heart, He controls our entire inward being and supplies and strengthens every inward part with Himself.
Faith is the substantiation of things not seen ([link]Heb. 11:1[/link]). Christ's indwelling is mysterious and abstract. We apprehend it not by our physical senses but by the sense of faith.

We are God's cultivated land and God's building ([link]1 Cor. 3:9[/link]). As God's cultivated land, we need to be rooted for our growth, and as God's building, we need to be grounded for our building up.

To experience Christ we need faith and love ([link]1 Tim. 1:14[/link]). Faith enables us to apprehend Christ, and love enables us to enjoy Him. Neither faith nor love are ours; they are His. His faith becomes our faith, by which we believe in Him, and His love becomes our love, by which we love Him. When we are rooted and grounded in His love, we grow and are built up in His life.

verse.text: May be full of strength to [note]1[/note]apprehend with [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]all the saints what the [note]3[/note]breadth and length and height and depth are
verse.note: Or, grasp, lay hold of intensively.
To apprehend the dimensions of Christ, we need all the saints, not individually but corporately.

The breadth, length, height, and depth are the dimensions of Christ. In our experience of Christ, we first experience the breadth of what He is, and then the length. This is horizontal. When we advance in Christ, we experience the height and depth of His riches. This is vertical. Our experience of Christ must become three-dimensional, like a cube, and must not be one-dimensional, like a line. In our experience of Christ we must go back and forth and up and down, that eventually our experience of Him may be a solid "cube." When our experience is like this, we cannot fall or be broken.

verse.text: And to know the [note]1[/note]knowledge-surpassing [xref]a[/xref]love of Christ,[separator]that you may be [xref]b[/xref]filled [note]2[/note]unto all the [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]fullness of [note]4[/note]God.
verse.note: The love of Christ is Christ Himself. Just as Christ is immeasurable, so also is His love; hence, it is knowledge-surpassing. Yet, we can know it by experiencing it.

When Christ makes His home in our hearts, and when we are full of strength to apprehend with all the saints the dimensions of Christ and to know by experience His knowledge-surpassing love, we will be filled unto all the fullness of God, which is the church, the corporate expression of God for the fulfillment of His intention.[br][br][i]The fullness of God[/i] implies that the riches of all that God is have become His expression. When the riches of God are in God Himself, they are His riches. But when the riches of God are expressed, they become His fullness ([link]John 1:16[/link]). All the fullness of God dwells in Christ ([link]Col. 1:19[/link]; [link]2:9[/link]). Through His indwelling, Christ imparts the fullness of God into our being that we may be filled even unto the fullness of God to be the practical manifestation of the church, in which God may be glorified in His expression ([link]v. 21[/link]).

In the New Testament the fullness is the expression through the completeness of the riches. This is the reason that in [link]v. 8[/link] Paul speaks of the unsearchable riches of Christ and that in [link]1:23[/link] and then in [link]4:13[/link] he speaks of the fullness of Christ. The riches of Christ are all that Christ is and has and all that He has accomplished, attained, and obtained. The fullness of Christ is the result and issue of our enjoyment of these riches. When the riches of Christ are assimilated into our being metabolically, they constitute us to be the fullness of Christ, the Body of Christ, the church, as His expression. First, in [link]1:23[/link] this expression is the fullness of Christ, and then in this verse it is the fullness of God, for the fullness of Christ, the embodiment of God, is the very fullness of the Triune God.

The Father ([link]v. 14[/link]) answers and fulfills the apostle's prayer through the Spirit ([link]v. 16[/link]) that Christ, the Son ([link]v. 17[/link]), may make His home in our hearts. Thus we are filled unto the fullness of God — the Triune God. This is the issue of the dispensing of the Triune God into our entire being.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]But [xref]a[/xref]to Him who is [xref]b[/xref]able to do superabundantly above all that we [note]2[/note]ask or think, according to the [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]power which operates in us,
verse.note: [link]Verses 16-19[/link] are the apostle's prayer. The word but makes [link]vv. 20-21[/link] a doxology. In his prayer the apostle prayed that the Father would strengthen the saints according to the riches of His glory. This implies that the glory of God can be wrought into the saints. In the doxology he said, "To Him be the glory" ([link]v. 21[/link]), implying that the glory of God, which has been wrought into the saints, returns to God. First, the glory of God is wrought into us; then it returns to God for His glorification. Isaac's wealth was first given to Rebekah for her beautification; then all the wealth came back to Isaac, with Rebekah, for his glorification ([link]Gen. 24:47[/link], [link]53[/link], [link]61-67[/link]). The apostle prayed that God would strengthen the saints according to His glory, "but" eventually God's glory, after being wrought into them, returns to Him along with the strengthened saints. This is the way in which God is glorified in the church.

Strictly, [i]ask or think[/i] here is in regard to the spiritual things related to the church, not in regard to material things. Concerning these spiritual things, we need to think as well as to ask. We might think more than we ask. God fulfills not only what we ask for the church but also what we think concerning the church, and God is able to do superabundantly above all that we ask or think, according to the power that operates in us.

The inward power, referred to in [link]1:19-20[/link], is God's resurrection power, not His creating power. God's creating power produces the material things in our environment ([link]Rom. 8:28[/link]), whereas God's resurrection power accomplishes within our inward being the spiritual things for the church.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]To Him be the [note]1[/note]glory in the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]church [note]3[/note]and in [note]4[/note]Christ Jesus unto [note]5[/note]all the generations forever and ever. Amen.
verse.note: See note [link]6[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 1[/link]. We are being strengthened into our inner man according to the riches of God's glory ([link]v. 16[/link]). This glory comes to us with God and, after being worked into us, will return to God with us. By means of this two-way traffic the church, as the firstfruits in the universe ([link]James 1:18[/link]), takes the lead to give glory to God. All the other families both in heaven and on earth will follow the church to glorify Him.
God's glory is wrought into the church, and He is expressed in the church. Hence, to God is the glory in the church; that is, God is glorified in the church.
God is glorified not only in the church but also in Christ. The word [i]and[/i] is used here to stress this point emphatically.

In the church the sphere of God's glorification is narrow, being limited to the household of the faith. But in Christ the sphere is much broader because Christ is the Head of all the families in the heavens and on earth ([link]1:22[/link]; [link]3:15[/link]). Hence, God's glorification in Christ is in the realm of all the families created by God, not only on earth but also in the heavens. This is in accord with [i]unto all the generations forever and ever,[/i] which means for eternity.
All the generations forever and ever constitute eternity. God's glorification in the church is mainly in this age, whereas God's glorification in Christ is for eternity.

verse.text: I beseech you therefore, [note]1[/note]I, the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]prisoner [xref]b[/xref]in the Lord, to [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]walk worthily of the [xref]d[/xref]calling with which you were [xref]e[/xref]called,
verse.note: This verse in part repeats [link]3:1[/link], where the apostle's exhortation in [link]chs. 4-6[/link] begins. This indicates that [link]3:2-21[/link] is parenthetical. See note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 3[/link].

See note [link]1[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 3[/link]. In [link]3:1[/link] Paul speaks of himself as "the prisoner of Christ Jesus," but here he says that he is "the prisoner in the Lord." To be a prisoner in the Lord is deeper than to be a prisoner of the Lord. As such a prisoner, Paul is a pattern for those who would walk worthily of God's calling.

This book is divided into two main sections. The first, composed of [link]chs. 1-3[/link], reveals the blessings and the position the church has obtained in Christ in the heavenlies. The second, comprising [link]chs. 4-6[/link], charges us concerning the living and responsibility the church should have in the Spirit on the earth. The basic charge is that we should walk worthily of God's calling, which is the totality of the blessings bestowed on the church, as revealed in [link]1:3-14[/link]. In the church, under the Triune God's abundant blessing, the saints should walk worthily of the Father's selection and predestination, the Son's redemption, and the Spirit's sealing and pledging. Hence, in [link]chs. 4-6[/link] we see, on the one hand, the living that the church should have, and, on the other hand, the responsibility that the church should bear.

verse.text: With all [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]lowliness and [xref]b[/xref]meekness, with [xref]c[/xref]long-suffering, bearing one another in [xref]d[/xref]love,
verse.note: To be lowly is to remain in a low estate, and to be meek is to not fight for oneself. We should exercise these two virtues in dealing with ourselves. To be long-suffering is to endure mistreatment. We should exercise this virtue in dealing with others. By these virtues we bear (not just tolerate) one another; that is, we do not forsake the troublesome ones but bear them in love. This is the expression of life.[br][br]These virtues are not found in our natural humanity but are in the humanity of Jesus. The fact that the virtues are mentioned here, before the oneness of the Spirit in [link]v. 3[/link], indicates that we must have these virtues in order to keep the oneness of the Spirit. This implies that in the uniting Spirit there is the transformed humanity, the humanity transformed by the resurrection life of Christ.

verse.text: Being diligent to [note]1[/note]keep the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]oneness of the Spirit in the uniting [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]bond of [xref]c[/xref]peace:
verse.note: Or, safeguard, preserve by guarding. The oneness of the Spirit is the Spirit Himself. To keep the oneness of the Spirit is to keep the life-giving Spirit. If we act apart from the Spirit, we are divisive and lose the oneness. If we stay in the life-giving Spirit, we keep the oneness of the Spirit.

To walk worthily of God's calling, to have the proper Body life, we first need to care for the oneness. This is crucial and vital to the Body of Christ. Strictly, oneness differs from unity. Unity is the state in which many people are united together, whereas oneness is the one entity of the Spirit within the believers, which makes them all one. This oneness is a person, Christ Himself, who is the Spirit dwelling within us. It is similar to the electricity flowing within many lamps, making them all one in the shining. In themselves, the lamps are separate, but in the electricity they are one.

Christ abolished on the cross all the differences that were due to ordinances. In so doing He made peace for His Body. This peace should bind all believers together and should thus become the uniting bond. The uniting bond of peace is the issue of the working of the cross. When we remain on the cross, we have peace with others. This peace becomes the uniting bond in which we keep the oneness of the Spirit.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]One [xref]a[/xref]Body and one Spirit, even as also you were called in one [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]hope of your [xref]c[/xref]calling;
verse.note: In exhorting us to safeguard the oneness, the apostle pointed out seven things that form the base of our oneness: one Body, one Spirit, one hope, one Lord, one faith, one baptism, and one God. These seven "ones" are of three groups. The first three form the first group, that of the Spirit with the Body as His expression. This Body, having been regenerated and being saturated with the Spirit as its essence, has the hope of being transfigured into the full likeness of Christ. The next three form the second group, that of the Lord with faith and baptism that we may be joined to Him. The last of the seven forms the third group, the one God and Father, who is the Originator and source of all. The Spirit as the Executor of the Body, the Son as the Creator of the Body, and God the Father as the Originator of the Body — all the three of the Triune God — are related to the Body. The Third of the Trinity is the first mentioned in [link]vv. 4-6[/link] because the main concern here is the Body, of which the Spirit is the essence and the life and life supply. The course is then traced back to the Son and to the Father.
The hope of glory ([link]Col. 1:27[/link]), which is the transfiguration of our body ([link]Phil. 3:21[/link]) and the manifestation of the sons of God ([link]Rom. 8:19[/link], [link]23-25[/link]).

verse.text: One [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Lord, one [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]faith, one [xref]c[/xref]baptism;
verse.note: This verse does not say "one Son," but "one Lord." In the Gospel of John it is the Son into whom we believe ([link]John 3:16[/link]), but in the Acts it is the Lord into whom we believe ([link]Acts 16:31[/link]). In the Epistles of John, the Son is for the imparting of life ([link]1 John 5:12[/link]), whereas in the Acts, the Lord, after His ascension, is for the exercising of authority ([link]Acts 2:36[/link]), a matter which concerns His headship. Hence, our believing in Him is related to both life and authority, for He is both our life and our Head. As the Head of the Body ([link]1:22[/link]), He is the Lord. Christians are divided because they neglect the Head; that is, they neglect the Lord's headship and authority.

Through faith we believe into the Lord ([link]John 3:36[/link]), and through baptism we are baptized into Him ([link]Gal. 3:27[/link]; [link]Rom. 6:3[/link]) and terminated in Adam ([link]Rom. 6:4[/link]). Through faith and baptism we have been transferred out of Adam into Christ, thereby being joined to the Lord ([link]1 Cor. 6:17[/link]). Immediately after believing in Christ, we should be baptized to complete the transfer.

verse.text: One [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]God and [xref]b[/xref]Father of [note]2[/note]all, who is [note]3[/note]over all and through all and in all.
verse.note: God is the Originator of all things, and the Father is the source of life for the Body of Christ.
Referring to all believers.

The Trinity is implied even here. [i]Over all[/i] refers mainly to the Father, [i]through all[/i] to the Son, and [i]in all[/i] to the Spirit. The Triune God eventually enters into us all by reaching us as the Spirit. The oneness of the Body of Christ is constituted of the Trinity of the Godhead — the Father as the source and origin being the Originator, the Son as the Lord and Head being the Accomplisher, and the Spirit as the life-giving Spirit being the Executor. The Triune God Himself, when realized and experienced by us in our daily life, is the fundamental basis and very foundation of our oneness.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]But to each one of us [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]grace was given according to the [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]measure of the [xref]c[/xref]gift of Christ.
verse.note: Concerning the Body of Christ, all the basic elements are one, but the gifts (the functions) are many and varied.

Here grace was given according to the gift; in [link]Rom. 12:6[/link] the gifts differ according to grace. Grace actually is the divine life that produces and supplies the gifts. In [link]Rom. 12[/link] it is the grace that produces the gift. Hence, the gift is according to grace. Here the grace is according to the gift, according to the measure of the gift. This is similar to our blood supplying the members of our body according to their size.
The measure of the gift of Christ is the size of a member of His Body.

verse.text: Therefore [i]the Scripture[/i] says, "Having [xref]a[/xref]ascended to the [note]1[/note]height, He led captive [note]2[/note]those taken captive and gave [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]gifts to men."
verse.note: [i]Height[/i] in the quotation from [link]Psa. 68:18[/link] refers to Mount Zion ([link]Psa. 68:15-16[/link]), which symbolizes the third heaven, where God dwells ([link]1 Kings 8:30[/link]). [link]Psalm 68[/link] implies that it was in the Ark that God ascended to Mount Zion after the Ark had won the victory. Verse 1 of [link]Psa. 68[/link] is taken from [link]Num. 10:35[/link]. This indicates that the background of [link]Psa. 68[/link] is God's move in the tabernacle with the Ark as its center. Wherever the Ark, a type of Christ, went, the victory was won. Eventually, this Ark ascended triumphantly to the top of Mount Zion. This portrays how Christ won the victory and ascended triumphantly to the heavens.

[i]Those[/i] refers to the redeemed saints, who were taken captive by Satan before being saved by Christ's death and resurrection. In His ascension Christ led them captive; that is, He rescued them from Satan's captivity and took them to Himself. This indicates that He conquered and overcame Satan, who had captured them by sin and death.[br][br]The Amplified New Testament renders "He led captive those taken captive" as "He led a train of vanquished foes." [i]Vanquished foes[/i] may refer to Satan, to his angels, and to us the sinners, again indicating Christ's victory over Satan, sin, and death. In Christ's ascension there was a procession of these vanquished foes, led as captives from a war, for a celebration of Christ's victory.

[i]Gifts[/i] here does not refer to the abilities or capacities for various services but to the gifted persons in [link]v. 11[/link] — apostles, prophets, evangelists, and shepherds and teachers. After conquering Satan and death and rescuing the sinners from Satan and death through His death and resurrection, Christ in His ascension made the rescued sinners themselves such gifts by means of His resurrection life and gave them to His Body for its building up.

verse.text: (Now this, "He [xref]a[/xref]ascended," what is it except that He also descended into the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]lower parts of the earth?
verse.note: Referring to Hades, which is under the earth. Christ went there after His death ([link]Acts 2:27[/link]).

verse.text: He who descended, He is also the One who ascended [xref]a[/xref]far above all the heavens that He might [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]fill all things.)
verse.note: First, in His incarnation Christ descended from heaven to earth. Then, in His death He descended farther, from earth to Hades. Eventually, in His resurrection He ascended from Hades to earth, and in His ascension, from earth to heaven. Through such a journey He cut the way that He might fill all things.

verse.text: And He Himself gave [note]1[/note]some as [xref]a[/xref]apostles and some as [xref]b[/xref]prophets and some as [xref]c[/xref]evangelists and some as [note]2[/note]shepherds and [xref]d[/xref]teachers,
verse.note: [i]Each one[/i] in [link]v. 7[/link] includes every member of the Body of Christ, each of whom has received a general gift; whereas the four kinds of gifted persons mentioned here are those who have been endued with a special gift.
According to the grammatical construction, [i]shepherds and teachers[/i] refers to a single class of gifted persons. A shepherd should know how to teach, and a teacher should be able to shepherd.

verse.text: For the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]perfecting of the saints [note]2[/note]unto the work of the [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]ministry, [note]2[/note]unto the [note]4[/note][xref]c[/xref]building up of the [xref]d[/xref]Body of Christ,
verse.note: Or, equipping, supplying the functions.
[i]Unto[/i] here means [i]resulting in, for the purpose of,[/i] or [i]with a view to.[/i]

The many gifted persons in the preceding verse have only one ministry, that is, to minister Christ for the building up of the Body of Christ, the church. This is the unique ministry in the New Testament economy ([link]2 Cor. 4:1[/link]; [link]1 Tim. 1:12[/link]).

According to the grammatical construction, the building up of the Body of Christ is the work of the ministry. Whatever the gifted persons in [link]v. 11[/link] do as the work of the ministry must be for the building up of the Body of Christ. However, this building up is not accomplished directly by the gifted ones but by the saints who have been perfected by the gifted ones.

verse.text: Until we all [note]1[/note]arrive at the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]oneness of the [xref]b[/xref]faith and of the full [xref]c[/xref]knowledge of the [note]3[/note][xref]d[/xref]Son of God, at a [note]4[/note][xref]e[/xref]full-grown man, at the measure of the stature of the [note]5[/note][xref]f[/xref]fullness of [note]3[/note]Christ,
verse.note: Or, attain to. This indicates that a process is required for us to attain to or arrive at the practical oneness.

In [link]v. 3[/link] the oneness of the Spirit is the oneness of the divine life in reality; in this verse the oneness is the oneness of our living in practicality. We already have the oneness of the divine life in reality. We need only to keep it. But we need to go on until we arrive at the oneness of our living in practicality. This aspect of oneness is of two things: the faith and the full knowledge of the Son of God. As revealed in [link]Jude 3[/link], [link]2 Tim. 4:7[/link], and [link]1 Tim. 6:21[/link], [i]the faith[/i] does not refer to the act of our believing but to the things in which we believe, such as the divine person of Christ and His redemptive work accomplished for our salvation. The full knowledge of the Son of God is the apprehension of the revelation concerning the Son of God for our experience. The more we grow in life, the more we will cleave to the faith and to the apprehension of Christ, and the more we will drop all the minor and meaner doctrinal concepts that cause divisions. Then we will arrive at, or attain to, the practical oneness; that is, we will arrive at a full-grown man, at the measure of the stature of the fullness of Christ.

[i]The Son of God[/i] refers to the Lord's person as life to us, whereas [i]Christ[/i] refers to His commission to minister life to us that we, the members of His Body, may have gifts for functioning. See note [link]16[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 16[/link].
A full-grown man is a mature man. Maturity in life is needed for the practical oneness.

The fullness of Christ is the Body of Christ ([link]1:23[/link]), which has a stature with a measure. To arrive at the measure of the stature of the fullness of Christ is necessary for the practical oneness. Hence, from the oneness in reality we need to proceed to the oneness in practicality until we arrive at the three things mentioned in this verse — the oneness, a full-grown man, and the measure of the stature of the fullness of Christ.

verse.text: That we may be no longer [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]little children tossed by [note]2[/note]waves and carried about by every [note]3[/note]wind of [xref]b[/xref]teaching in the [note]4[/note]sleight of men, in [xref]c[/xref]craftiness with a view to a [note]5[/note]system of error,
verse.note: Lit., infants. The same Greek word as for [i]child[/i] in [link]Gal. 4:1[/link], referring to those believers who are young in Christ, lacking maturity in life ([link]1 Cor. 3:1[/link]).

The waves stirred up by the winds of different teachings ([link]1 Tim. 1:3-4[/link]), doctrines, concepts, and opinions are sent by Satan to entice the believers in order to carry them away from Christ and the church. It is difficult for the infants in Christ to discern these. The only way to escape from the waves that are stirred up by the winds is to grow in life, and the safe way to grow in life is to stay in the proper church life with Christ and the church as the safeguard.
Any teaching, even a scriptural one, that distracts believers from Christ and the church is a wind that carries believers away from God's central purpose.

The Greek word for [i]sleight[/i] refers to the cheating of dice players. The word for [i]craftiness[/i] denotes the trickery employed by gamblers. The teachings that become winds, carrying believers away from the central lane of Christ and the church, are deceptions instigated by Satan in his subtlety, with the sleight of men, in order to frustrate God's eternal purpose, which is to build up the Body of Christ.

The dividing teachings are organized and systematized by Satan to cause serious error and thus damage the practical oneness of the Body life. The sleight is of men, but the system of error is of Satan and is related to the deceitful teachings that are designed by the evil one to distract the saints from Christ and the church life.

verse.text: But [note]1[/note]holding to truth in [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]love, we may [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]grow up into Him in all things, who is the [note]4[/note][xref]c[/xref]Head, Christ,
verse.note: Or, truthing it. This is in contrast to the sleight and the error in [link]v. 14[/link]. To be carried away by the winds of teaching in the sleight of men unto a system of error is to not hold to truth. [i]Truth[/i] here means things that are true. According to the context, it must refer to Christ and His Body: both are true things. We should hold in love to these true things that we may grow up into Christ.

This is not our own love but the love of God in Christ, which becomes the love of Christ in us, by which we love Christ and the fellow members of His Body. It is in such a love that we hold to truth, that is, to Christ with His Body, and are kept from being influenced by the winds of teaching and from bringing in elements that are foreign to the Body.
To be no longer little children ([link]v. 14[/link]), we need to grow up into Christ. This is to have Christ increase in us in all things until we attain to a full-grown man ([link]v. 13[/link]).
[i]Head[/i] here indicates that our growth in life by the increase of Christ should be the growth of the members in the Body under the Head.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Out from whom [xref]a[/xref]all the Body, being [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]joined together and being [note]2[/note]knit together through every [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]joint of [note]4[/note]the rich supply [note]5[/note]and [i]through[/i] the [note]6[/note]operation in the [xref]d[/xref]measure of [note]7[/note]each one part, [note]8[/note]causes the [note]9[/note][xref]e[/xref]growth of the Body unto the [xref]f[/xref]building up of itself in [note]10[/note][xref]g[/xref]love.
verse.note: To grow in life is to grow into the Head, Christ, but to operate in the Body of Christ is to operate out from Him. First, we grow up into the Head; then we have something that is out from the Head for the building up of the Body.
[i]Joined[/i] implies the thought of joining by fitting; [i]knit[/i] implies the thought of interweaving.
[i]Every joint of the rich supply[/i] refers to the specially gifted persons, such as those mentioned in [link]v. 11[/link].
In Greek the article here is emphatic. Hence, [i]the[/i] rich supply must be the particular supply, the supply of Christ.
Most of the ancient MSS read, according to the operation.
Or, functioning. The same Greek word as in [link]3:7[/link] and [link]Col. 1:29[/link], and of the same origin as [i]operations[/i] in [link]1 Cor. 12:6[/link].

[i]Each one part[/i] refers to each member of the Body. Through the growth in life and the development of gifts, each member of the Body of Christ has its own measure, which operates for the growth of the Body.
The Body of Christ causes the growth of itself through the supplying joints and the operating parts.
The growth of the Body of Christ is the increase of Christ in the church, which results in the building up of the Body by the Body itself.
See note [link]15[sup]2[/sup][/link].

verse.text: This therefore I say and [note]1[/note]testify [xref]a[/xref]in the Lord, that you no longer [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]walk as the [xref]c[/xref]Gentiles also [xref]d[/xref]walk in the [note]3[/note][xref]e[/xref]vanity of their mind,
verse.note: The apostle's word here was not only his exhortation but also his testimony. His exhortation was his living.

[link]Verses 1-16[/link] deal with the living and the function of the Body of Christ. Now, in [link]vv. 17-32[/link] our daily life is touched. [link]Verses 17-24[/link] give us the principles of our daily walk, and [link]vv. 25-32[/link] give us the details.

The Gentiles are the fallen people, who become vain in their reasonings ([link]Rom. 1:21[/link]). They walk without God in the vanity of their mind, being controlled and directed by their vain thoughts. Whatever they do according to their fallen mind is vanity, void of reality.

verse.text: Being [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]darkened in their understanding, alienated from the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]life of God because of the [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]ignorance which is in them, because of the [note]4[/note][xref]d[/xref]hardness of their heart;
verse.note: When the mind of fallen people is filled with vanity, their understanding is darkened regarding the things of God. Thus, they are alienated, separated, from the life of God.

This is the uncreated, eternal life of God, which man did not have at the time of creation. After being created, man with the created human life was placed before the tree of life ([link]Gen. 2:8-9[/link]) that he might receive the uncreated divine life. But man fell into the vanity of his mind and became darkened in his understanding. Now, in such a fallen condition man is unable to touch the life of God until he repents (has his mind turned to God) and believes in the Lord Jesus to receive God's eternal life ([link]Acts 11:18[/link]; [link]John 3:16[/link]).

[i]Ignorance[/i] denotes not only a lack of knowledge but also an unwillingness to know. Because of the hardness of his heart, fallen man does not approve of knowing the things of God ([link]Rom. 1:28[/link]). Therefore, his understanding is darkened so that he does not know God.
The hardness of fallen man's heart is the source of the darkness in his understanding and the vanity of his mind.

verse.text: Who, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]being past feeling, have [xref]b[/xref]given themselves over to lasciviousness to work all uncleanness in greediness.
verse.note: [i]Feeling[/i] here refers mainly to the consciousness of one's conscience. Hence, [i]being past feeling[/i] means not caring for one's conscience. After man fell, God ordained that man should be under the ruling of his conscience. But instead of regarding his conscience, fallen man gave himself over to lasciviousness and greedy lust.

verse.text: But you did not so [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]learn Christ,
verse.note: Christ is not only life to us but also an example ([link]John 13:15[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 2:21[/link]). In His life on earth He set up a pattern, as revealed in the Gospels. Then He was crucified and resurrected to become the life-giving Spirit that He might enter into us to be our life. We learn from Him ([link]Matt. 11:29[/link]) according to His example, not by our natural life but by Him as our life in resurrection. To learn Christ is simply to be molded into the pattern of Christ, that is, to be conformed to the image of Christ ([link]Rom. 8:29[/link]).

verse.text: If indeed you have heard Him and have been [xref]a[/xref]taught in Him as the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]reality is in Jesus,
verse.note: [i]The reality is in Jesus[/i] refers to the actual condition of the life of Jesus as recorded in the four Gospels. In the godless walk of the nations, the fallen people, there is vanity. But in the godly life of Jesus there is truth, reality. Jesus lived a life in which He did everything in God, with God, and for God. God was in His living, and He was one with God. This is what is meant by [i]the reality is in Jesus.[/i] We, the believers, who are regenerated with Christ as our life and are taught in Him, learn from Him as the reality is in Jesus.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]That you [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]put off, as regards your [note]3[/note]former manner of life, the [note]4[/note][xref]b[/xref]old man, which is being corrupted according to the lusts of [note]5[/note]the deceit,
verse.note: [link]Verses 22[/link] and [link]24[/link] show us what we have been taught: that we put off the old man and put on the new man. Our putting off of the old man and putting on of the new man is a manifestation of our having learned Christ.
In baptism we put off the old man. Our old man was crucified with Christ ([link]Rom. 6:6[/link]) and was buried in baptism ([link]Rom. 6:4a[/link]).
The former manner of life is a walk in the vanity of the mind ([link]v. 17[/link]).
The old man is of Adam, who was created by God but became fallen through sin.
The article here is emphatic, and [i]the deceit[/i] is personified. Hence, [i]the deceit[/i] refers to the deceiver, Satan, from whom come the lusts of the corrupted old man.

verse.text: And [i]that[/i] you be [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]renewed in the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]spirit of your mind
verse.note: Our being renewed is for our transformation into the image of Christ ([link]Rom. 12:2[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 3:18[/link]).

This is the regenerated spirit of the believers, which is mingled with the indwelling Spirit of God. Such a mingled spirit spreads into our mind, thus becoming the spirit of our mind. It is in such a spirit that we are renewed for our transformation.

verse.text: And [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]put on the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]new man, which was [xref]c[/xref]created according to [note]3[/note]God in [note]4[/note][xref]d[/xref]righteousness and [note]4[/note][xref]e[/xref]holiness of [note]5[/note]the [xref]f[/xref]reality.
verse.note: It was in baptism that we put on the new man ([link]Rom. 6:4b[/link]).

The new man is of Christ. It is His Body, created in Him on the cross ([link]2:15-16[/link]). It is not individual but corporate ([link]Col. 3:10-11[/link]). In this corporate new man Christ is all and in all — He is all the people and in all the people. See note [link]11[sup]9[/sup] in Col. 3[/link].[br][br]This book reveals first that the church is the Body of Christ ([link]1:22-23[/link]), the kingdom of God, the household of God ([link]2:19[/link]), and the temple, the dwelling place of God ([link]2:21-22[/link]). Here it reveals in addition that the church is the new man. This is the highest aspect of the church. The church is an assembly of the called-out ones. This is the initial aspect of the church. From here, the apostle went on to mention the fellow citizens of the kingdom of God and the members of the household of God. These are higher than the initial aspect, but not as high as the church as the Body of Christ. Yet the new man is higher still than the Body of Christ. Thus, the church is not just an assembly of believers, a kingdom of heavenly citizens, a household of God's children, or even a Body for Christ. It is in its ultimate, uttermost aspect a new man to accomplish God's eternal purpose. As the Body of Christ, the church needs Christ as its life, whereas as the new man, the church needs Christ as its person. This new corporate person should live a life like that which Jesus lived on earth, that is, a life of reality that expresses God and causes God to be realized as the reality by man. Hence, the new man is the focus of the apostle's exhortation in this section ([link]vv. 17-32[/link]).

The old man was created outwardly according to the image of God but without God's life and nature ([link]Gen. 1:26-27[/link]), whereas the new man was created inwardly according to God Himself and with God's life and nature ([link]Col. 3:10[/link]).

Righteousness is to be right with God and with man according to God's righteous way, while holiness is godliness and devoutness before God (see note [link]75[sup]1[/sup] in Luke 1[/link]). Righteousness is mainly toward men, and holiness is mainly toward God.

The article here is emphatic. As the deceit in [link]v. 22[/link], related to the old man, is the personification of Satan, so the reality here, related to the new man, is the personification of God. The deceit is the devil, and the reality is God. This reality was exhibited in the life of Jesus, as mentioned in [link]v. 21[/link]. In the life of Jesus, righteousness and holiness of the reality were continuously manifested. It was in the righteousness and holiness of this reality, which is God realized and expressed, that the new man was created.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Therefore having [xref]a[/xref]put off the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]lie, speak [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]truth each one with his neighbor, for we are [xref]d[/xref]members one of another.
verse.note: [link]Verses 25-32[/link] give a description of our practical daily living in learning Christ.

[i]The lie[/i] refers to anything that is false in nature. Because we put off the old man, we also put off everything that is false in nature. Hence, we speak truth, that is, we speak the things that are true.

verse.text: Be [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]angry, yet do [xref]b[/xref]not sin; do not let the [xref]c[/xref]sun go down on your [note]2[/note][xref]d[/xref]indignation,
verse.note: To be angry is not a sin, but with it there is the possibility of committing sin. We should not continue in anger but should relinquish it before the sun sets.
Or, vexation.

verse.text: Neither [note]1[/note]give place to the [xref]a[/xref]devil.
verse.note: According to the context, to continue in anger is to give place to the devil. In nothing should we give any place to him.

verse.text: He who steals should [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]steal no more, but rather should [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]labor, working with his own [xref]c[/xref]hands in [note]3[/note]that which is respectable, that he may have [i]something[/i] to [note]2[/note][xref]d[/xref]share with him who has need.
verse.note: Even in a book of such high revelation, the apostle still touched certain low, practical things, such as stealing and anger.
Stealing is due mainly to slothfulness and greed. Hence, the apostle charged him who steals to labor instead of being slothful, and to share with others what he gains instead of being greedy.
Or, that which is good. See [link]Titus 3:8[/link], [link]14[/link].

verse.text: Let no [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]corrupt word proceed out of your mouth, but only that which is good for [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]building up, according to the need, that it may give [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]grace to those who hear.
verse.note: Lit., rotten; signifying what is noxious, offensive, or worthless.
Our conversation should not corrupt others but should build them up.

Grace is Christ as our enjoyment and supply. Our word should convey such grace to others. The word that builds up others always ministers Christ as grace to the hearer.[br][br]The apostle's exhortation in [link]vv. 17-32[/link] took grace and reality ([link]vv. 21[/link], [link]24[/link], [link]29[/link]) as its basic elements. The apostle wanted us to live, as Jesus did, a life full of grace and reality ([link]John 1:14[/link], [link]17[/link]). Grace is God given to us for our enjoyment, and reality is God revealed to us as our reality. When we live and speak reality ([link]vv. 21[/link], [link]24[/link]), we express God as our reality, and others receive God as grace for their enjoyment ([link]v. 29[/link]).

verse.text: And do not [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]grieve the Holy [note]2[/note]Spirit of God, [note]3[/note]in whom you were [note]4[/note][xref]b[/xref]sealed [note]5[/note]unto the day of [note]6[/note][xref]c[/xref]redemption.
verse.note: To grieve the Holy Spirit is to displease Him. The Holy Spirit abides in us forever ([link]John 14:16-17[/link]), never leaving us. Hence, He is grieved when we do not walk according to Him ([link]Rom. 8:4[/link]), that is, when we do not live according to the principle of reality with grace in the details of our daily walk.

The apostle's exhortation in [link]vv. 17-32[/link] not only takes grace and reality as the basic elements but also takes the life of God ([link]v. 18[/link]) and the Spirit of God as the basic factors on the positive side, and the devil ([link]v. 27[/link]) as a factor on the negative side. It is by the life of God in the Spirit of God, and by not giving place to the devil, that we can live a life full of grace and reality, as the Lord Jesus did.
I.e., in the Holy Spirit as the element. We were sealed in the element of the Holy Spirit. This shows that God has sealed us with the Holy Spirit as the sealing element.
See note [link]13[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

From the time that we are saved, the Holy Spirit as the seal in us seals us continually with the element of God that we may be transformed in nature until our body is completely transfigured and redeemed. Hence, this verse says that we were sealed with the Holy Spirit unto the day of the redemption of our body.
See note [link]14[sup]4[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: Let all bitterness and anger and wrath and clamor and evil speaking be [xref]a[/xref]removed from you, with all malice.

And be [xref]a[/xref]kind to one another, [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]tenderhearted, [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]forgiving one another, even as [note]3[/note]God in Christ also [note]4[/note]forgave you.
verse.note: The Greek word has the same origin as [i]moved with compassion[/i] in [link]Matt. 9:36[/link] and [i]inward parts[/i] in [link]Phil. 1:8[/link]. Only by enjoying Christ as grace and reality can we be tenderhearted and thus be able to forgive one another.
Or, showing grace to.
In his exhortation in this section ([link]vv. 17-32[/link]), the apostle presented God as the pattern of our daily life. In the Spirit and by His life, we can forgive as God forgives.
Or, showed grace to.

verse.text: Be therefore [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]imitators of God, as beloved children;
verse.note: What a glorious fact that since we are God's beloved children, we can be imitators of God! As the children of God, we have His life and nature. We imitate Him not by our natural life but by His divine life. It is by our Father's divine life that we, His children, can be perfect, as He is ([link]Matt. 5:48[/link]).

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]walk in [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]love, even as [note]2[/note]Christ also [xref]c[/xref]loved [note]3[/note]us and gave Himself up for us, an [note]4[/note]offering and a [note]4[/note][xref]d[/xref]sacrifice to God for a [note]5[/note][xref]e[/xref]sweet-smelling savor.
verse.note: As grace and reality (truth) are the basic elements in [link]4:17-32[/link], so love and light ([link]vv. 8-9[/link], [link]13[/link]) are the basic elements in the apostle's exhortation in [link]5:1-33[/link]. Grace is the expression of love, and love is the source of grace. Truth is the revelation of light, and light is the origin of truth. God is love and God is light ([link]1 John 4:8[/link]; [link]1:5[/link]). When God is expressed and revealed in the Lord Jesus, His love becomes grace and His light becomes truth. After we have, in the Lord, received God as grace and realized Him as truth, we come to Him and enjoy His love and light. Love and light are deeper than grace and truth. Hence, the apostle first took grace and truth as the basic elements for his exhortation, and then love and light. This implies that he wanted our daily walk to grow deeper, to progress from the outward elements to the inward.[br][br]Love is the inner substance of God, whereas light is the expressed element of God. The inward love of God is sensible, and the outward light of God is visible. Our walk in love should be constituted of both the loving substance and the shining element of God. These should be the inner source of our walk. They are deeper than grace and truth.

In [link]4:32[/link] the apostle presented God as the pattern of our daily walk. Here he set forth Christ as the example of our living. In [link]4:32[/link] God in Christ is our pattern, since in that section God's grace and reality (truth) expressed in the life of Jesus are taken as the basic elements. But here Christ Himself is our example, since in this section love expressed by Christ to us ([link]vv. 2[/link], [link]25[/link]) and light shined by Christ upon us ([link]v. 14[/link]) are taken as the basic elements.
Some ancient authorities read, you.

An offering is for fellowship with God, whereas a sacrifice is for redemption from sin. Christ gave Himself up for us as both an offering, that we might have fellowship with God, and a sacrifice, that He might redeem us from sin.

In loving us, Christ gave Himself up for us. This was for us, but it was a sweet-smelling savor to God. In following His example, our walk in love should be not only something for others but also a sweet-smelling savor to God.

verse.text: But [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]fornication and all uncleanness or greediness, let it not even be named among you, as is fitting for [note]2[/note]saints,
verse.note: Nothing is more damaging to mankind than fornication. It is especially damaging to God's purpose and intention in creating man and to the believers' church life in the Body of Christ. This is based on [link]1 Cor. 5[/link].
Persons who are separated unto God and saturated with God and who live a life according to God's holy nature.

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]obscenity and foolish talking or sly, filthy jesting, which are not becoming, but rather the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]giving of thanks.
verse.note: To give thanks to God is to speak God as truth, whereas to talk foolishly or to jest filthily is to speak Satan as falsehood.

verse.text: For this you [note]1[/note]realize, [note]2[/note]knowing that every fornicator or unclean person or greedy person (who is an idolater) has no inheritance in the [note]3[/note][xref]a[/xref]kingdom of Christ and of God.
verse.note: The Greek word denotes subjective knowledge.
The Greek word denotes objective knowledge.

The kingdom of Christ is the millennium ([link]Rev. 20:4[/link], [link]6[/link]; [link]Matt. 16:28[/link]) and also the kingdom of God ([link]Matt. 13:41[/link], [link]43[/link] and notes). The believers have been regenerated into the kingdom of God ([link]John 3:5[/link]), and they are in the church life, living in the kingdom of God today ([link]Rom. 14:17[/link]). Not all believers, only the overcoming ones, will participate in the millennium. In the coming age the unclean, defeated ones will have no inheritance in the kingdom of Christ and of God, the millennium. See notes [link]20[sup]3[/sup] in Matt. 5[/link] and [link]28[sup]1[/sup] in Heb. 12[/link].

verse.text: Let no one deceive you with [xref]a[/xref]vain words, for because of these things the [xref]b[/xref]wrath of God is coming upon the [xref]c[/xref]sons of disobedience.
Therefore do not be [xref]a[/xref]partakers with them;

For you were [xref]a[/xref]once [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]darkness but are now [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]light [xref]d[/xref]in the Lord; [note]2[/note][xref]e[/xref]walk as [note]3[/note][xref]f[/xref]children of light
verse.note: We were once not only dark but darkness itself. Now we are not only the children of light but light itself ([link]Matt. 5:14[/link]). As light is God, so darkness is Satan. We were darkness because we were one with Satan. Now we are light because we are one with God in the Lord.
[link]Verse 2[/link] tells us to walk in love, and this verse tells us to walk as children of light.
As God is light, so we, the children of God, are the children of light.

verse.text: (For the [xref]a[/xref]fruit of the light [i]consists[/i] in all [note]1[/note]goodness and [xref]b[/xref]righteousness and [xref]c[/xref]truth),
verse.note: Goodness is the nature of the fruit of the light; righteousness is the way or the procedure by which the fruit of the light is produced; and truth is the reality, the real expression (God Himself), of the fruit of the light. The fruit of the light must be good in nature, righteous in procedure, and real in expression, that God may be expressed as the reality of our daily walk.[br][br]The fruit of the light in goodness, righteousness, and truth is related to the Triune God. Goodness denotes God the Father, for the only one who is good is God ([link]Matt. 19:17[/link]). Righteousness denotes God the Son, for Christ came to accomplish God's purpose according to God's righteous procedure ([link]Rom. 5:17-18[/link], [link]21[/link]). Truth denotes God the Spirit, for He is the Spirit of reality ([link]John 14:17[/link]). Truth also denotes the expression of the fruit in the light.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Proving what is well pleasing to the Lord.
And do not [xref]a[/xref]participate in the [note]1[/note]unfruitful [xref]b[/xref]works of darkness, but rather even [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]reprove [i]them.[/i]
verse.note: The unfruitful works of darkness are vanity, whereas the fruit of the light is truth, reality ([link]v. 9[/link]).
Or, expose, uncover.

verse.text: For the things which are done by them in secret it is shameful even to speak of.
But all things which are [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]reproved are made manifest by the light; for everything that makes [xref]b[/xref]manifest is light.
verse.note: Or, exposed, uncovered.

verse.text: Therefore He says, [xref]a[/xref]Awake, [note]1[/note]sleeper, and [xref]b[/xref]arise from the [xref]c[/xref]dead, and [note]2[/note]Christ will [xref]d[/xref]shine on you.
verse.note: The sleeping one who needs the reproving mentioned in [link]vv. 11[/link] and [link]13[/link] is also a dead one. He needs to awake from sleep and arise from the dead.
When we reprove or expose anyone who is sleeping and dead in darkness, Christ will shine on him. Our reproving or exposing in light is Christ's shining.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Look therefore carefully how you [xref]a[/xref]walk, not as unwise, but as [xref]b[/xref]wise,
verse.note: To live by being filled in spirit ([link]vv. 15-21[/link]) is the fifth aspect of a walk that is worthy of God's calling. The first four aspects of such a worthy walk are keeping the oneness, growing up into the Head, learning Christ, and living in love and light. The issue of having these four aspects of a worthy walk is that we are spontaneously filled in our spirit. Out of this inward filling will come submission, love, obedience, care, and all the other virtues of a proper Christian life, church life, family life, and community life. What a life we have when we demonstrate the five aspects of a walk that is worthy of God's calling!

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Redeeming the time, because the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]days are evil.
verse.note: I.e., seizing every favorable opportunity. This is to be wise in our walk ([link]v. 15[/link]).

In this evil age ([link]Gal. 1:4[/link]) every day is an evil day full of pernicious things that cause our time to be used ineffectively, to be reduced, and to be taken away. Therefore, we must walk wisely that we may redeem the time, seizing every available opportunity.

verse.text: Therefore do not be foolish, but [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]understand what the [xref]b[/xref]will of the Lord is.
verse.note: To understand the will of the Lord is the best way to redeem our time ([link]v. 16[/link]). Most of our time is wasted because we do not know the will of the Lord.

verse.text: And do not be [note]1[/note]drunk with [xref]a[/xref]wine, in which is dissoluteness, but be [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]filled in [xref]c[/xref]spirit,
verse.note: To be drunk with wine is to be filled in the body, whereas to be filled in the spirit (our regenerated spirit, not God's Spirit) is to be filled with Christ ([link]1:23[/link]) unto the fullness of God ([link]3:19[/link]). To be drunk with wine in our physical body causes us to become dissolute, but to be filled in our spirit with Christ, with the fullness of God, causes us to overflow with Christ in speaking, singing, psalming, and giving thanks to God ([link]vv. 19-20[/link]) and also causes us to subject ourselves to one another ([link]v. 21[/link]).

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Speaking to one another in [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]psalms and hymns and spiritual songs, singing and psalming with your heart to the Lord,
verse.note: [link]Verses 19-21[/link] modify [i]be filled in spirit[/i] in [link]v. 18[/link]. Psalms, hymns, and spiritual songs are not only for singing and psalming but also for speaking to one another. Such speaking, singing, psalming, giving of thanks to God ([link]v. 20[/link]), and subjecting of ourselves to one another ([link]v. 21[/link]) are not only the outflow of being filled in spirit but also the way to be filled in spirit.

Psalms are long poems, hymns are shorter poems, and spiritual songs are poems that are shorter still. All are needed in order for us to be filled with the Lord and to overflow with Him in our Christian life.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Giving thanks [note]1[/note]at all times for all things [note]2[/note]in the name of our Lord Jesus Christ to [i]our[/i] God and Father,
verse.note: We should give thanks to God the Father not only in good times but at all times, and not only for good things but for all things. Even in bad times we should give thanks to God our Father for the bad things.
The reality of the name of the Lord is His person. To be in the Lord's name is to be in His person, in Himself. This implies that we should be one with the Lord in giving thanks to God.

verse.text: Being [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]subject to [note]2[/note]one another in the [note]3[/note]fear of Christ:
verse.note: Being subject to one another also is a way to be filled in spirit with the Lord ([link]v. 18[/link]) and is the overflow of being filled. This is to live in the way of being filled in spirit with all the riches of Christ unto the fullness of God.
Our subjection should be to one another — the younger ones to the older ones, and also the older ones to the younger ones ([link]1 Pet. 5:5[/link]).

According to the context of the succeeding verses, to be in the fear of Christ is to fear offending Him as the Head. This is related to His headship ([link]v. 23[/link]) and involves our being subject to one another. See note [link]33[sup]2[/sup][/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Wives, [i]be[/i] [xref]b[/xref][i]subject[/i] [note]2[/note]to your [note]3[/note]own husbands as to the Lord;
verse.note: The relationship between wives and husbands is connected to the matter of being filled in spirit. Only by being filled in our spirit can we have a proper married life, a figure of the relationship between Christ and the church.

This is one kind of subjection implied in [link]v. 21[/link]. In his exhortation concerning married life, the apostle dealt first with wives, since wives, like Eve in [link]Gen. 3[/link], deviate from the right way more easily than husbands. [link]First Peter 3:7[/link] says that the wife is the weaker vessel. In his exhortations concerning wives and husbands, children and parents, and slaves and masters, Paul took care of first the weaker side and then the stronger side.

Most wives appreciate and respect others' husbands; hence, the apostle exhorted wives to be subject to [i]their own[/i] husbands as to the Lord, regardless of what kind of husbands they have. In the same principle, when Paul addressed husbands, he exhorted them to love [i]their own[/i] wives ([link]vv. 28[/link], [link]33[/link]). If we desire to live according to reality, by grace, and in love and light, we must not compare our wife or husband with others'.

verse.text: For a husband is [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]head of the wife as also Christ is [xref]b[/xref]Head of the church, He Himself [i]being[/i] the [note]2[/note]Savior of the Body.
verse.note: The husband as the head of the wife typifies Christ as the Head of the church.

Christ is not only the Head of the church but also the Savior of the Body. His being the Head is a matter of authority, whereas His being the Savior is a matter of love. We must be subject to Him as our Head, and we must love Him as our Savior.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]But as the church is subject to Christ, so also [i]let[/i] the wives [i]be subject[/i] to their husbands in [note]2[/note]everything.
verse.note: The thought here is this: although husbands are not the saviors of their wives in the way that Christ is the Savior of the church, wives still need to be subject to their husbands as the church is to Christ.

According to the divine ordination, the subjection of wives to their husbands should be absolute, without any choice. This does not mean that they should obey their husbands in everything. Obeying is different from being subject. With obedience, the emphasis is on compliance, whereas with subjection, the emphasis is on subordination. In sinful things, things against God and the Lord, wives should not obey their husbands. However, they should still be in subjection to them. In a similar situation, Daniel's three friends disobeyed the Babylonian king's order to worship the idol, yet still subjected themselves to the king's authority ([link]Dan. 3:13-23[/link]).

verse.text: Husbands, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]love your wives even [note]2[/note]as Christ also [xref]b[/xref]loved the church and gave Himself up for her
verse.note: The opposite of being subject is to rule; however, the apostle did not exhort husbands to rule over their wives but to love them. In married life, the wife's obligation is to be subject and the husband's is to love. The wife's subjection plus the husband's love constitutes a proper married life and typifies the normal church life, in which the church is subject to Christ and Christ loves the church. Love is the very element, the inner substance, of God ([link]1 John 4:8[/link], [link]16[/link]). The goal of this book is to bring us into God's inner substance that we may enjoy God as love and enjoy His presence in the sweetness of the divine love, and thereby love others as Christ did.
A husband's love for his wife must be like Christ's love for the church; he must be willing to pay a price, even to die for his wife.

verse.text: That He might [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]sanctify her, cleansing [i]her[/i] by the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]washing of the [note]3[/note]water in the [note]4[/note][xref]c[/xref]word,
verse.note: Christ's purpose in giving Himself up for the church is to sanctify her, not only separating her to Himself from everything common but also saturating her with His element that she may be His counterpart. He accomplishes this by cleansing her by the washing of the water in the word.

Lit., laver. In Greek the definite article is used before this word, causing it to refer to [i]the[/i] laver, the laver that was known to all the Jews. In the Old Testament the priests used the laver to wash away their earthly defilement ([link]Exo. 30:18-21[/link]). Now the laver, the washing of the water, washes us from defilement.

According to the divine concept, water here refers to the flowing life of God, which is typified by flowing water ([link]Exo. 17:6[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 10:4[/link]; [link]John 7:38-39[/link]; [link]Rev. 21:6[/link]; [link]22:1[/link], [link]17[/link]). The washing of the water here is different from the washing of the redeeming blood of Christ. The redeeming blood washes away our sins ([link]1 John 1:7[/link]; [link]Rev. 7:14[/link]), whereas the water of life washes away the blemishes of the natural life of our old man, such as the "spot or wrinkle or any such things" mentioned in [link]v. 27[/link]. In separating and sanctifying the church, the Lord first washes away our sins with His blood ([link]Heb. 13:12[/link]) and then washes away our natural blemishes with His life. We are now in such a washing process, that the church may be holy and without blemish ([link]v. 27[/link]).

The Greek word denotes an instant word. The indwelling Christ as the life-giving Spirit is always speaking an instant, present, living word to metabolically cleanse away the old and replace it with the new, causing an inward transformation. The cleansing by the washing of the water of life is in the word of Christ. This indicates that in the word of Christ there is the water of life. This is typified by the laver situated between the altar and the tabernacle ([link]Exo. 38:8[/link]; [link]40:7[/link]).

verse.text: That He might [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]present the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]church to Himself [note]3[/note]glorious, not having [note]4[/note]spot or wrinkle or any such things, but that she would be [note]5[/note][xref]c[/xref]holy and [xref]d[/xref]without blemish.
verse.note: In the past, Christ as the Redeemer gave Himself up for the church ([link]v. 25[/link]) for redemption and the impartation of life ([link]John 19:34[/link]); in the present, He as the life-giving Spirit is sanctifying the church through separation, saturation, transformation, growth, and building up; and in the future, He as the Bridegroom will present the church to Himself as His counterpart for His satisfaction. Therefore, Christ's loving the church is to separate and sanctify her, and His separating and sanctifying the church are to present her to Himself.

In this section of exhortation the apostle presented another aspect of the church, that of the bride. This aspect reveals that the church comes out of Christ, as Eve came out of Adam ([link]Gen. 2:21-22[/link]), that it has the same life and nature as Christ, and that it becomes one with Him as His counterpart, as Eve became one flesh with Adam ([link]Gen. 2:24[/link]). The church as the new man is a matter of grace and reality, whereas the church as the bride of Christ is a matter of love and light. The apostle's exhortation in [link]ch. 4[/link] is focused on the new man, which has grace and reality as its basic elements, whereas his exhortation in this chapter is focused on the bride of Christ, which has love and light as its basic substances. In grace and reality we should walk as the new man, and in love and light we should live as the bride of Christ.
Glory is God expressed. Hence, to be glorious is to be God-expressing. Eventually, the church presented to Christ will be a God-expressing church.
The spot here signifies something of the natural life, and wrinkles are related to oldness. Only the water of life can metabolically wash away such defects by the transformation of life.
To be holy is to be saturated with Christ and transformed by Christ, and to be without blemish is to be spotless and without wrinkle, having nothing of the natural life of our old man.

verse.text: In the same way the husbands also ought to [xref]a[/xref]love their own wives as their own bodies; he who loves his own wife loves himself.
For no one ever hated his own flesh, but [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]nourishes and [xref]b[/xref]cherishes it, even as Christ also the church,
verse.note: To nourish is to feed us with the living word of the Lord. To cherish is to nurture us with tender love and foster us with tender care, outwardly softening us through tender warmth that we may have soothing, comfortable rest inwardly. This is the way Christ cares for the church, His Body.

verse.text: Because we are [xref]a[/xref]members of His [xref]b[/xref]Body.
[xref]a[/xref]For this cause a man shall [note]1[/note]leave his father and mother and shall be joined to his wife, and the two shall be [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]one flesh.
verse.note: This is God's ordination according to His economy ([link]Gen. 2:24[/link]; [link]Matt. 19:5[/link]).
Lit., into one flesh.

verse.text: This [xref]a[/xref]mystery is great, but I speak with regard to [note]1[/note]Christ [xref]b[/xref]and the church.
verse.note: Christ and the church as one spirit ([link]1 Cor. 6:17[/link]), typified by a husband and wife as one flesh, are the great mystery.

verse.text: Nevertheless you also, each one of you, in the same way [xref]a[/xref]love [note]1[/note]your own wife as yourself; and the wife should [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]fear her husband.
verse.note: Lit., his own wife as himself.
Because a wife should respect her husband as the head, the one who typifies Christ as the Head of the church, she should fear her husband in the fear of Christ ([link]v. 21[/link]).

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Children, obey your parents [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]in the Lord, for this is [note]3[/note]right.
verse.note: In exhorting the children and the parents, the apostle dealt with the children first, since trouble comes mostly from the children.[br][br][link]Verses 1-9[/link], which deal with the relationship between children and fathers and between slaves and masters, are inserted between the section on the church as the bride ([link]5:22-33[/link]) and the section on the church as the warrior ([link]vv. 10-20[/link]). If we neglect the points dealt with in [link]vv. 1-9[/link], we cannot be a proper bride or a proper warrior. In the exhortations in these verses, Paul made one key point, which is a very important lesson for us to learn: for the sake of the church life, we need to have a proper human living in this present age.

[i]In the Lord[/i] indicates that children need to obey their parents (1) by being one with the Lord, (2) not by themselves but by the Lord, and (3) not according to their natural concept but according to the Lord's word.
Or, just, reasonable. For children to obey their parents is not only right but also just.

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]"Honor your father and mother," which is the [note]2[/note]first commandment with a promise,
verse.note: Honoring is different from obeying. Obeying is an action, whereas honoring is an attitude. It is possible for children to obey their parents without honoring them. In order to honor their parents, children need an honoring attitude, an honoring spirit. All children need to learn to obey their parents and, at the same time, honor them.
This is not only the first commandment with a promise but also the first commandment concerning man's relationship with man ([link]Exo. 20:12[/link]).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]"That it may be [note]1[/note]well with you and that you may [note]1[/note]live long on the earth."
verse.note: To have it well with ourselves is to be prosperous in material blessings, and to live long is to have longevity. Prosperity and longevity are God's blessings in this life to those who honor their parents. If we wish to prolong our days and enjoy blessings, we must learn to obey and honor our parents. The commandment to honor our parents is the first commandment with a promise.

verse.text: And fathers, do not [note]1[/note]provoke your children to anger, but [xref]a[/xref]nurture them in the discipline and [note]2[/note]admonition of the Lord.
verse.note: Provoking children to anger damages them by stirring up their flesh. Not to provoke his children to anger requires that a father deal with his anger by leaving it on the cross. In this way he is able to render suitable discipline to his children.

Admonition includes instruction. Parents should instruct their children with the Word of God ([link]Deut. 6:6-7[/link]), teaching them to know the Bible. However, how the children develop depends on God's mercy.

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Slaves, [note]2[/note]be obedient to those who are your masters according to the flesh with [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]fear and trembling, in [note]4[/note][xref]c[/xref]singleness of your heart, [note]5[/note][xref]d[/xref]as to Christ;
verse.note: Concerning the relationship between slaves and masters, the apostle exhorted the slaves first, because the source of trouble was mostly with them.

In the apostle's time slaves were purchased by their masters, and the masters had the right over their lives. Some slaves and masters became brothers in the church. As brothers in the church, they were equal and without distinction (see [link]Col. 3:11[/link]), but at home those who were slaves still were obligated to obey the brothers who were their masters according to flesh.
Fear is the inward motive for service, and trembling the outward attitude.
To be single is to be pure in motive, without a mixed purpose.
The relationship between slaves and masters also is a type of our relationship with Christ, who is our Master. We should be like slaves, obeying Him in singleness of heart.

verse.text: Not with eye-service as [xref]a[/xref]men-pleasers but [note]1[/note]as [xref]b[/xref]slaves of Christ, doing the [xref]c[/xref]will of God [note]2[/note]from the [xref]d[/xref]soul;
verse.note: If a brother who is a slave stands in his position and obeys his master, he is in the eyes of the Lord a slave of Christ, doing the will of God, and he serves as serving the Lord and not men ([link]v. 7[/link]).
From the soul here equals from the heart. This means to serve not only with the physical body but also with the heart.

verse.text: With good will [xref]a[/xref]serving as slaves, [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]as [i]serving[/i] the Lord and not men;
verse.note: See note [link]6[sup]1[/sup][/link].

verse.text: Knowing that whatever good thing each one does, [note]1[/note]this he will receive back from the Lord, whether [i]he is[/i] a [xref]a[/xref]slave or a free man.
verse.note: Whatever good thing we do, we will receive back the same from the Lord, and it will become a reward to us.

verse.text: And masters, do the same things toward them, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]giving up your threatening, knowing that both their Master and yours is in the heavens, and there is [xref]b[/xref]no respect of persons with Him.
verse.note: The masters, who had the right over the lives of their purchased slaves, needed to give up their threatening, because the Lord in the heavens was the real Master of both them and the slaves.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Finally, [note]2[/note]be [note]3[/note][xref]a[/xref]empowered [note]4[/note][xref]b[/xref]in the Lord and in the [xref]c[/xref]might of His strength.
verse.note: The passage from [link]1:1-6:9[/link] completes the revelation on the positive side concerning the church's fulfilling of God's eternal purpose; yet on the negative side, concerning the church's dealing with God's enemy, there is more to be covered.
This implies that we need to exercise our will strongly.

This word in Greek has the same root as the word for [i]power[/i] in [link]1:19[/link]. To deal with God's enemy, to fight against the evil forces of darkness, we need to be empowered with the greatness of the power that raised Christ from the dead and seated Him in the heavens, far above all the evil spirits in the air.
In the spiritual warfare against Satan and his evil kingdom, we can fight only in the Lord, not in ourselves. Whenever we are in ourselves, we are defeated.

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Put on the [note]2[/note]whole [xref]b[/xref]armor of God that you may be able to [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]stand against the [note]4[/note][xref]d[/xref]stratagems of the [xref]e[/xref]devil,
verse.note: On the positive side, in the first five chapters the church is portrayed in many ways for the fulfilling of God's eternal purpose. On the negative side, the church is seen here as a warrior for the defeating of God's enemy, the devil. To defeat God's enemy, we need to put on the whole armor of God. "Put on" is an imperative, a command. God has provided the armor for us, but He does not put it on for us. Rather, we ourselves must put it on, exercising our will to cooperate with Him.

To fight the spiritual warfare, we need not only the power of the Lord but also the armor of God. Our weapons do not avail, but God's armor, even the whole armor of God, does avail.[br][br]The whole armor of God is for the entire Body of Christ, not for any individual member of the Body. The church is a corporate warrior, and the believers are parts of this unique warrior. Only the corporate warrior, not any individual believer, can wear the whole armor of God. We must fight the spiritual warfare in the Body, not as individuals.

In [link]ch. 2[/link] we sit with Christ in the heavenlies ([link]2:6[/link]), and in [link]chs. 4[/link] and [link book="Eph."]5[/link] we walk ([link]4:1[/link], [link]17[/link]; [link]5:2[/link], [link]8[/link], [link]15[/link]) in His Body on the earth. Then in [link]ch. 6[/link] we stand in His power in the heavenlies. To sit with Christ is to participate in all His accomplishments; to walk in His Body is to fulfill God's eternal purpose; and to stand in His power is to fight against God's enemy.
The evil plan of the devil.

verse.text: For our wrestling is not against [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]blood and flesh but against [note]2[/note]the [xref]b[/xref]rulers, against the authorities, against the [xref]c[/xref]world-rulers of [note]3[/note]this [xref]d[/xref]darkness, against the spiritual [i]forces[/i] of evil in the [note]4[/note][xref]e[/xref]heavenlies.
verse.note: [i]Blood and flesh[/i] refers to men. Behind men of blood and flesh are the evil forces of the devil, which are against God's purpose. Hence, our wrestling, our fighting, must not be against men but against the spiritual forces of evil in the heavenlies.

The rulers, the authorities, and the world-rulers of this darkness are the rebellious angels, who followed Satan in his rebellion against God and who now rule in the heavenlies over the nations of the world — such as the prince of Persia and the prince of Greece in [link]Dan. 10:20[/link]. This indicates that the devil, Satan, has his kingdom of darkness ([link]Matt. 12:26[/link]; [link]Col. 1:13[/link]), in which he occupies the highest position and in which the rebellious angels are under him.
[i]This darkness[/i] refers to today's world, which is fully under the dark ruling of the devil, who rules through his evil angels.

[i]Heavenlies[/i] here refers to the air ([link]2:2[/link]). Satan and his spiritual forces of evil are in the air. But we are seated in the third heaven above them ([link]2:6[/link]). In fighting a battle, the position above the enemy is very important strategically. Satan and his evil forces are under us, and they are destined to be defeated by us.

verse.text: Therefore [note]1[/note]take up the whole [xref]a[/xref]armor of God that you may be able to [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]withstand in the [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]evil day, and having done all, to [note]4[/note][xref]d[/xref]stand.
verse.note: It is the whole armor of God, not just a part or some parts of it, that we need for the spiritual warfare. To take up the whole armor, the Body of Christ is needed; individual believers are not sufficient for this.
To withstand is to stand against. To stand is crucial in fighting.
[link chapter="5"]Verse 16[/link] in [link]ch. 5[/link] says that the days are evil. In this evil age every day is an evil day because Satan, the evil one, is at work every day.
In fighting we need to stand to the end. Having done all, we still must stand.

verse.text: Stand therefore, [note]1[/note]having [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]girded your loins with [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]truth and having [note]4[/note]put on the [xref]c[/xref]breastplate of [xref]d[/xref]righteousness
verse.note: From this point to the end of [link]v. 16[/link] we are given a description of how to stand.
The girding of our loins is for the strengthening of our entire being.

According to the usage of this word in [link]ch. 4[/link] — see notes [link chapter="4"]15[sup]1[/sup][/link] (on [i]truth[/i]), [link]21[sup]1[/sup][/link] (on [i]reality[/i]), and [link]24[sup]5[/sup][/link] (on [i]reality[/i]) in [link]ch. 4[/link] — [i]truth[/i] here refers to God in Christ as reality in our living, that is, God becoming our reality and experience in our living. This is actually Christ Himself lived out by us ([link]John 14:6[/link]). Such truth, such reality, is the girdle that strengthens our whole being for the spiritual warfare.

To put on the breastplate of righteousness is to cover our conscience, signified by the breast. Satan is the one who accuses us. In fighting against him we need a conscience void of offense. Regardless of how clear we feel our conscience is, it needs to be covered with the breastplate of righteousness. To be righteous is to be right with both God and man. If we are just a little wrong with either God or man, Satan will accuse us, and there will be holes in our conscience through which all our faith and boldness will leak out. Hence, we need the covering of righteousness to protect us from the enemy's accusation. Such righteousness is Christ ([link]1 Cor. 1:30[/link]).

verse.text: And having [note]1[/note]shod your [xref]a[/xref]feet with the [note]2[/note]firm foundation of the [xref]b[/xref]gospel of [xref]c[/xref]peace;
verse.note: We shoe our feet to strengthen our stand in the battle. It is not for walking a way or running a course but for fighting the battle.

[i]Firm foundation[/i] may also be rendered [i]readiness.[/i] Here it means the establishing of the gospel of peace. Christ made peace for us, with both God and man, on the cross, and this peace has become our gospel ([link]2:13-17[/link]). This gospel of peace has been established as a firm foundation, as a readiness with which our feet may be shod. Being thus shod, we will have a firm footing that we may stand to fight the spiritual warfare. The peace for such a firm foundation also is Christ ([link]2:14[/link]).

verse.text: Besides all these, having [note]1[/note]taken up the [xref]a[/xref]shield of [note]2[/note]faith, with which you will be able to quench all the flaming [note]3[/note]darts of the [xref]b[/xref]evil one.
verse.note: The shield of faith is taken up to protect ourselves against the attacks of the enemy.

We need to have our loins girded with truth, our conscience covered with righteousness, our feet shod with peace, and our entire being protected with the shield of faith. If we live by God as reality (truth), we have righteousness ([link]4:24[/link]), and righteousness issues in peace ([link]Heb. 12:11[/link]; [link]Isa. 32:17[/link]). Having all these, we can easily have faith as a shield against the evil one's flaming darts. Christ is the Author and Perfecter of such faith ([link]Heb. 12:2[/link]). For us to stand firmly in the battle, we need to be equipped with all these four items of God's armor.
