The flaming darts are Satan's temptations, proposals, doubts, questions, lies, and attacks. Flaming darts were used by fighters in the apostle's time. The apostle used this term to illustrate Satan's attacks on us.

verse.text: And receive the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]helmet of salvation and the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]sword of the Spirit, [note]3[/note]which [i]Spirit[/i] is the [note]4[/note][xref]c[/xref]word of God,
verse.note: Receiving the helmet of salvation is for covering our mind, our mentality, against the negative thoughts shot in by the evil one. Such a helmet, such a covering, is God's salvation. Satan injects threats, worries, anxieties, and other weakening thoughts into our mind. God's salvation is the covering that we take up against all these. Such a salvation is the saving Christ whom we experience in our daily life ([link]John 16:33[/link]).
Among the six items of God's armor, this is the only one that is used for attacking the enemy.

The antecedent of [i]which[/i] is [i]Spirit,[/i] not [i]sword,[/i] indicating that the Spirit is the word of God. Both the Spirit and the word are Christ ([link]2 Cor. 3:17[/link]; [link]Rev. 19:13[/link]). Christ as the Spirit and the word furnishes us with a sword as an offensive weapon to defeat and slay the enemy.

The instant word spoken at the moment by the Spirit in any situation. The sword, the Spirit, and the word are one. When the constant word in the Bible becomes the instant word, that word is the Spirit as the sword that kills the enemy.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]By means of all [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]prayer and petition, praying at [xref]b[/xref]every time in [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]spirit and [note]4[/note][xref]d[/xref]watching unto this in [note]5[/note]all perseverance and [note]6[/note]petition concerning all the saints,
verse.note: This phrase modifies the verb [i]receive[/i] in [link]v. 17[/link], which tells us to receive not only the helmet of salvation but also the word of God. This indicates that we need to receive the word of God by means of all prayer and petition. We need to pray to receive the word of God.[br][br]The whole armor of God is composed of six items. Prayer may be considered the seventh. It is the unique, crucial, and vital means by which we apply the other items, making the armor available to us in a practical way.
Prayer is general and petition is particular; both are needed that we might have a proper, overcoming church life.

This is our regenerated spirit, indwelt by the Spirit of God. It may be considered the mingled spirit — the spirit that is our spirit mingled with God's Spirit. In praying, the main faculty that we should use is this spirit.
We need to be watchful, on the alert, for the maintaining of this prayer life.
To maintain a life of prayer, we need all perseverance, a constant, persistent care.
This indicates that we need to pray in a particular way for all the saints.

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]for me, that [note]1[/note]utterance may be given to me in the opening of my mouth, to make known in [xref]b[/xref]boldness the [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]mystery of the gospel,
verse.note: Or, word, speech, expression.
The mystery of the gospel is Christ and the church for the fulfillment of God's eternal purpose ([link]5:32[/link]). See [link]Rom. 16:25[/link] and note 3.

verse.text: For which I am an [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]ambassador in a [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]chain, that in it I would speak [xref]c[/xref]boldly, as I [xref]d[/xref]ought to speak.
verse.note: An ambassador is one sent by a particular authority to contact certain people. Here this word implies that the apostle was one who was sent by God, the highest authority in the universe, to contact certain people.
A coupling chain, a chain that bound the prisoner to his guard.

verse.text: But [xref]a[/xref]that you also may know the things concerning me, how I am doing, [xref]b[/xref]Tychicus, the beloved brother and faithful [note]1[/note]minister [xref]c[/xref]in the Lord, will [note]2[/note]make all things known to you.
verse.note: A ministering servant.
This kind of fellowship is necessary and beautiful. Today such a loving concern between the apostles and the churches needs to be restored.

verse.text: Him I have sent to you for this very thing, that you may know the things concerning us and that he may [xref]a[/xref]comfort your hearts.
[note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Peace to the brothers and [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]love with faith [note]3[/note]from God the Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.
verse.note: In the beginning of the book the apostle's greeting is first with grace as the enjoyment and then with peace as the result of the enjoyment ([link]1:2[/link]). But in the conclusion the elements are presented vice versa, progressing from the result, peace, to the enjoyment, grace. After we have come into peace, we still need grace, indicating that our experience is from grace to grace.

The reason the apostle inserted [i]love[/i] between [i]peace[/i] and [i]grace[/i] is that the only way we can be kept in a situation of peace is by continually enjoying the Lord in love. Paul realized that love is crucial. He spoke of love in relation to peace and grace, indicating thereby that love is needed to preserve us in a condition of peace.[br][br]Love with faith is the means by which we partake of and experience Christ ([link]1 Tim. 1:14[/link]). Faith is for receiving Him ([link]John 1:12[/link]), and love is for enjoying Him ([link]John 14:23[/link]). Here it is not faith and love nor love and faith, but love [i]with[/i] faith. This indicates that we need faith as a match and support for our love. Love with faith is needed. This is the conclusion of the book on the church. The church needs to enjoy Christ in love with faith, which operates through love ([link]Gal. 5:6[/link]). Love comes from God to us, and faith goes from us to God. By means of this traffic of love and faith, peace remains our portion. We are kept in peace by the coming of God's love to us and by the going of our faith to Him. This traffic also keeps us in the continual supply of grace, in the enjoyment of the Lord ([link]v. 24[/link]).
Love is from God; it originates with God, not with us. Eventually, however, God's love becomes our love. God's love for us becomes our love for Him.

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Grace be with all those who [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]love our Lord Jesus Christ in [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]incorruptibility.
verse.note: Grace is needed for us to live a church life that fulfills God's eternal purpose and solves God's problem with His enemy.

The enjoyment of the Lord as grace is with those who love Him. In this book the phrase [i]in love,[/i] which is rich in feeling, is used repeatedly ([link]1:4[/link]; [link]3:17[/link]; [link]4:2[/link], [link]15-16[/link]; [link]5:2[/link]). Later, the church in Ephesus was rebuked by the Lord because she had lost her first love toward Him ([link]Rev. 2:4[/link]). One of the main points revealed in this book is that the church, which is the Body of Christ, is also the bride of Christ, Christ's wife. With the Body, the emphasis is on taking Christ as life; with the wife, the emphasis is on loving Christ. Therefore, this book emphasizes and also concludes with our love toward the Lord. The church in Ephesus, the recipient of this Epistle, failed in the matter of loving the Lord. Such a failure became the source of and main reason for the failure of the church throughout the ages ([link]Rev. 2-3[/link]).

For the proper church life we need to love the Lord in incorruptibility, that is, in and according to all the crucial things revealed and taught in the six chapters of this book, such as the church as the Body of Christ, the new man, the economy of God's mystery, the oneness of the Spirit, reality and grace, light and love, and the items of God's armor, all of which are incorruptible. For the sake of the church, our love toward the Lord must be in these incorruptible things.
